case_title: Ch. NASEER-UD-DIN vs GOVERNMENT OF WEST PAKISTAN THROUGH CHIEF SECRETARY, CIVIL SECRETARIAT, LAHORE AND 2 OTHERS
respondent: GOVERNMENT OF WEST PAKISTAN THROUGH CHIEF SECRETARY, CIVIL SECRETARIAT, LAHORE AND 2 OTHERS

key_issues.issue: Consultation with the Public Service Commission
key_issues.contention: Consultation with the Public Service Commission was obligatory under Article 186 of the 1962 Constitution, notwithstanding the amendment made by the Provincial Governor in 1965.
The finding of inefficiency recorded against the petitioner was not warranted by the facts and evidence presented.

facts.description: Petitioner joined service as Field Qanungo in 1947, promoted to Naib-Tehsildar in 1954, and later appointed Tehsildar in 1959.
Charge-sheet served in 1962 regarding mutation correction and another in 1964 for irregular disposal of rent suits.
Inquiry held by Special Judge (Anti-Corruption)-cum-Enquiry Officer in 1965 found petitioner guilty of inefficiency but exonerated him of corruption.
Punishment finalized in 1967, reducing petitioner to Naib-Tehsildar for two years.

legal_analysis.interpretation: Consultation with the Public Service Commission is mandatory unless the Governor provides otherwise by an order.
Terms and conditions of service for pre-Constitution employees are protected, but procedural changes like consultation requirements are not substantive rights.

conclusion: The petition was dismissed as the amendment exempting consultation with the Public Service Commission was valid, and the findings of inefficiency were supported by evidence.
